case_name: Manager of Sree Krishna Oil Mills v. Kharagpore Municipality

facts.text: This is Criminal Appeal No. 50 of 1969.

anchor.surface_text: Criminal Appeal No. 50 of 1969. Appeal from the judgment

facts.text: Appeal from the judgment and order dated December 24, 1968 of the Calcutta High Court in Criminal Revisions No. 235 of 1966.

anchor.surface_text: Appeal from the judgment and order dated December 24, 1968 of the Calcutta High Court in Criminal Revisions No. 235 of 1966.

facts.text: Appeal by certificate under Art. 134(1)(c) of the Constitution.

anchor.surface_text: This appeal is by certificate under Art. 134 1   c  of the Constitution.

facts.text: Appellant is the Manager of Sree Krishna Oil Mills, Midnapore.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant is the Manager of Sree Krishna Oil Mills, Midnapore, the proprietor of which was one Srilal Bajoria.

facts.text: Proprietor of Sree Krishna Oil Mills was Srilal Bajoria.

anchor.surface_text: the proprietor of which was one Srilal Bajoria. Both these persons were tried jointly for an offence under S. 7 1 /16 1  a  i  of the Prevention of Food Adulteration Act, 1954-

facts.text: Srilal Bajoria was acquitted.

anchor.surface_text: The proprietor Srilal Bajoria was acquitted but the appellant was sentenced to one year rigorous imprisonment.

facts.text: Appellant sentenced to one year rigorous imprisonment by trial court.

anchor.surface_text: The proprietor Srilal Bajoria was acquitted but the appellant was sentenced to one year rigorous imprisonment.

facts.text: On July 10, 1964, at about 11 A.M., appellant was going in a truck carrying 100 tins of mustard oil and was stopped by Food Inspector of Kharagpore Municipality.

anchor.surface_text: On July 10, 1964, at about II A.M. the appellant was going in a truck carrying 100 tins of mustard oil and was stopped by the Food Inspector, Kharagpore Municipality.

facts.text: Appellant informed Food Inspector that the oil was manufactured at Sree Krishna Oil Mills, Midnapore.

anchor.surface_text: On being questioned by the Food Inspector the appellant informed him that the oil which he was carrying was manufactured at Sree Krishna Oil Mills, Midnapore.

facts.text: Food Inspector took three samples according to the provisions of the Act.

anchor.surface_text: As the Food Inspector suspected that this oil may have been adulterated, he took three samples according to the provisions of the Act.

facts.text: Public Analyst reported on August 5, 1964, that saponification value was 181.6, Iodine value 107.2, B.R. reading at 40C was 60.1, and sample was adulterated.

anchor.surface_text: The Public Analyst on examining the sample sent to him reported on August 5, 1964, that saponification value of the oil was 181.6, Iodine value 107.2 and B. R. reading at 40C was 60.1 and was of the opinion that the sample of mustard oil was adulterated vide Ext. 5.

facts.text: Sanction for prosecution obtained from Chairman of Municipality on August 19, 1964 by Shri K C. Chaki.

anchor.surface_text: It is companytended on behalf of the appellant that the sanction to prosecute the appellant was given by the Chairman of Kharagpore Municipality-Shri K C. Chaki-on August 19, 1964.

facts.text: Appellant prosecuted before Magistrate, 1st Class, Midnapore.

anchor.surface_text: After obtaining the sanction for prosecution from the Chairman of the Municipality, the appellant was prosecuted before, the Magistrate, 1st Class, Midnapore.

facts.text: Appellant pleaded not guilty before Magistrate.

anchor.surface_text: He pleaded number guilty but on the evidence and the report of the Public Analyst he was companyvicted and sentenced as aforesaid.

facts.text: Magistrate convicted appellant based on evidence and Public Analyst report.

anchor.surface_text: He pleaded number guilty but on the evidence and the report of the Public Analyst he was companyvicted and sentenced as aforesaid.

facts.text: Appeal to Sessions Judge dismissed.

anchor.surface_text: An appeal to the Sessions Judge was without success.

facts.text: Revision before High Court dismissed.

anchor.surface_text: Thereafter the appellant filed a revision before the High Court and that was also dismissed.

facts.text: Municipality resolution dated July 28, 1960 authorised Chairman to perform functions under Prevention of Food Adulteration Act.

anchor.surface_text: In companypliance with the aforesaid power under s. 51 of the Bengal Municipal Act, the Municipality by resolution dated July 28, 1960 authorised the Chairman to perform all the functions and exercise the. powers of the Local Authority within the meaning of the Prevention of Food Adulteration Act, 1954.  Exe. 7 .

facts.text: Fresh election of Chairman held after 1960 resolution.

anchor.surface_text: It is true that a fresh election of the Chairman was held after the resolution of the Municipality but that does number deprive the new Chairman of the power to grant sanction in under that, resolution.

facts.text: Kharagpore Municipality passed another resolution on August 18, 1965 authorising Chairman for sanctions under the Act.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant in Criminal Miscellaneous Petitions Nos. 450 515 of 1970 seeks permission to allow him to adduce additional evidence to show that there was another resolution by the Kharagpore Municipality dated August 18, 1965, which had given a, fresh authorisation to the Chairman to grant sanctions for prosecution under the Act

facts.text: Public Analyst performed only three tests out of seven required under A 17.06 of Appendix B to the Rules.

anchor.surface_text: Nextly it has been strenuously urged before us on behalf of the appellant that the report of the Public Analyst is number a companylete report in that out of the seven tests that he had to make under A 17.06 of Appendix B to the Rules he had only made three tests

facts.text: Appellant filed Criminal Miscellaneous Petitions Nos. 450 and 515 of 1970 for additional evidence.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant in Criminal Miscellaneous Petitions Nos. 450 515 of 1970 seeks permission to allow him to adduce additional evidence

facts.text: Appellant has been on bail since 1964 for nearly seven years.

anchor.surface_text: in this case having regard to the fact that the appellant has been on bail since 1964 for a period of nearly seven years,

facts.text: Supreme Court reduced sentence to two months rigorous imprisonment and fine of Rs. 1000, failing which one month further RI.

anchor.surface_text: interests of justice would be served if the sentence of one year is reduced to two months rigorous imprisonment and the appellant is further directed to pay a fine of Rs. 1,000/- failing which to be directed to undergo a further term of rigorous imprisonment for one month.

facts.text: Prosecution prior to amendment of S.16(1) effective March 1, 1965.

anchor.surface_text: It was urged that the prosecution of the appellant was prior to the amendment of sub-s.  1  of S. 16 of the Prevention of Food Adulteration Act with effect from March 1, 1965,
This appeal is by certificate under Art. 134 1   c  of the Constitution.

holdings.text: The challenge to the validity of the sanction is misconceived; the Chairman of a Municipality duly authorised by the Municipality can accord sanction for prosecution of offences under the Act.

anchor.surface_text: It appears to us that the challenge to the validity of the sanction is misconceived. As pointed out by the High Court, s. 51 of the Bengal Municipal Act, 1932, enumerates the powers of the Chairman as under Save as hereinafter provided, the Chairman shall for the transaction of the business connected with this Act or for the purpose of making any order authorised thereby, exercise all the powers, vested by this Act in the Commissioners and whereby any other law power is vested in the Commissioners for any purpose, the Chairman may transact any business or make any order authorised by that law in the exercise. of that power, unless it is otherwise expressly provided in that law. Section 20 of the Act provides for sanction of the Local Authority for prosecutions under the Act which includes a Municipality. Reading these two provisions together the Chairman of a Municipality duly authorised by the Municipality can accord sanction for prosecution of offences under the Act.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Harmonious construction of s.20 PFA and s.51 Bengal Municipal Act empowers authorised Chairman to sanction prosecution.

holdings.text: The power granted by the resolution dated July 28, 1960 is a general power exercisable by any Chairman for the time being; fresh election does not deprive new Chairman of power to grant sanction.

anchor.surface_text: In compliance with the aforesaid power under s. 51 of the Bengal Municipal Act, the Municipality by resolution dated July 28, 1960 authorised the Chairman to perform all the functions and exercise the. powers of the Local Authority within the meaning of the Prevention of Food Adulteration Act, 1954.  Exe. 7 . This power, it may be noticed, is not granted to any particular Chairman Eo nomine, but is a general power exercisable by any Chairman for the time being of the Municipality. It is true that a fresh election of the Chairman was held after the resolution of the Municipality but that does not deprive the new Chairman of the power to grant sanction in under that, resolution.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Resolution authorises office of Chairman generally, not specific individual; applies textual interpretation.

holdings.text: Under s.15(2) Bengal Municipal Act, Municipality is body corporate with perpetual succession; authorisation continues unless rescinded.

anchor.surface_text: The High Court has pointed out, and we think rightly, that under s. 15 2  of the Bengal Municipal Act, the Municipality is a body corporate and it has perpetual succession, if so any authorisation granted by it is not limited to the Chairman then in office, but will continue unless otherwise rescinded.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Municipality's corporate status ensures continuity of resolutions.

holdings.text: No case made out to adduce additional evidence of 1965 resolution; it does not invalidate prior sanction.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant in Criminal Miscellaneous Petitions Nos. 450 515 of 1970 seeks permission to allow him to adduce additional evidence to show that there was another resolution by the Kharagpore Municipality dated August 18, 1965, which had given a, fresh authorisation to the Chairman to grant sanctions for prosecution under the Act which would show that the previous authorisation was not really valid when sanction was given to prosecute the appellant. Apart from the fact that, no case has been made out to adduce any fresh evidence, the resolution itself has been passed after the sanction for the prosecution was. given and even that resolution as can be noticed is in similar terms to the earlier resolution passed by the Municipality.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Evidence irrelevant as post-sanction and similar; procedural bar on new evidence.

holdings.text: Omission to report on other tests does not make Public Analyst report ineffective; if saponification test fails standard under A.17.06, sample is adulterated.

anchor.surface_text: It is true that the Public Analyst in his report has only indicated the result of the three tests out of which two tests were as indicated in A 17.06 while only one, namely, the saponification test was said to have exceeded the maximum on the strength of which the Public Analyst reported that the sample was adulterated. Omission to report on the other four tests does not, in our view make the reporter ineffective or the report inconclusive. Even assuming that the other four tests are normal, if the saponification test alone did not conform to the standards indicated in A 17.06 of Appendix B to the Rules the sample cannot be said to have come up to the standard and, therefore, it is adulterated.

holdings.reasoning_summary: One failing test sufficient for non-conformity under s.2(i) PFA.

holdings.text: Standards prescribed in Appendix B to the Rules under ss.3, 23 PFA and r.5 are conclusive; non-conformity renders article adulterated u/s.2(i).

anchor.surface_text: We cannot allow any fresh evidence to be used, nor do we think that the decisions referred to, even if they justify that contention, can alter or vary the standard fixed in exercise of the powers conferred by the Act in Appendix B to the Rules. Section 3 of the, Act authorises the Central Government to constitute a Committee called the Central Committee for Food Standards to advise the Central Government and the State Governments on matters arising out of the administration of the Act and to carry out the other functions assigned to it under the Act. Under s. 23 1 b of the Act the Central Government may, after consultation with the Committee and subject to the condition of previous publication, make rules defining the standards of quality for, and fixing the limits of variability permissible in respect of, any article of food. It is in exercise of this power that r. 5 was made authorising standards of quality of the various articles of food specified in Appendix B to the Rules. In view of this provision any article of food which does not conform to the standards specified in Appendix B to the Rules which under s. 2 1 of the Act is said to be adulterated because the quality or purity of the article falls below the prescribed standard or its constituents are present in quantities which are in excess of the prescribed limits of variability.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Rule-making authority under PFA makes standards binding; purposive to protect public health.

holdings.text: Public Analyst report admissible as evidence u/s.13(5) unless superseded by Central Food Laboratory certificate.

anchor.surface_text: Under s. 13 5 of the Act any document purporting to be a report signed by a Public Analyst, unless it has been superseded under sub-s. 3 , or any document purporting to be a certificate signed by the Director of the Central Food Laboratory, may be used as evidence of the facts stated therein in any proceeding under the Act or under ss. 272 to 276 of the Indian Penal Code.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Statutory presumption of admissibility; appellant failed to seek CFL analysis.

holdings.text: Sentence reduced to two months rigorous imprisonment and fine of Rs.1000 (default one month RI) considering pre-amendment law, long bail period, near conformity of tests, proprietor acquitted.
holdings.reasoning_summary: Discretionary reduction under unamended s.16(1); balancing circumstances despite public interest in strictness.

Section 3 of the, Act authorises the Central Government to constitute a Committee called the Central Committee for Food Standards to advise the Central Government and the State Governments on matters arising out of the administration of the Act and to carry out the other functions assigned to it under the Act.

anchor.surface_text: In this regard it was pointed out by Shah, J., as he then was, speaking for this Court in Andhra Pradesh Grain and Seed Merchants Association and others v. Union of India Anr.  1  The various items in the Schedule setting out standards of quality use technical expressions with which an ordinary, retail dealer may not be familiar, and also set out percentages of components which the dealer with the means at his command cannot verify. But by s. 3, the Central Government has to set up the Central Committee for Food Standards to advise the Central and the State Governments on matters arising out of the administration of the Act

precedents.case_name: Andhra Pradesh Grain and Seed Merchants Association and others v. Union of India and Anr.
precedents.cited_proposition: standards of quality for food articles are prescribed after consultation with expert Central Committee for Food Standards and are binding even if technical and not verifiable by ordinary dealers
precedents.cited_holding: The various items in the Schedule setting out standards of quality use technical expressions with which an ordinary, retail dealer may not be familiar, and also set out percentages of components which the dealer with the means at his command cannot verify. But by s. 3, the Central Government has to set up the Central Committee for Food Standards to advise the Central and the State Governments on matters arising out of the administration of the Act. Under s. 23(1)(b) the Central Government makes rules prescribing the standards of quality and the limits of variability permissible in any article of food. The rules are made after consultation with the Committee for Food Standards.

outcome.relief_summary: Conviction upheld. Sentence reduced from one year rigorous imprisonment to two months rigorous imprisonment and fine of Rs. 1,000/-, in default further one month rigorous imprisonment. Appeal and petitions dismissed subject to modification.
directions: Sentence of one year rigorous imprisonment reduced to two months rigorous imprisonment
Appellant to pay fine of Rs. 1,000/-
In default of payment of fine, undergo further rigorous imprisonment for one month
Criminal Miscellaneous Petitions Nos. 450 and 515 of 1970 dismissed

edges.explanation: h1 explicitly addresses the issue by stating 'The challenge to the validity of the sanction is misconceived'

anchor.surface_text: It appears to us that the challenge to the validity of the sanction is misconceived. As pointed out by the High Court, s. 51 of the Bengal Municipal Act, 1932, enumerates the powers of the Chairman as under Save as hereinafter provided, the Chairman shall for the transaction of the business connected with this Act or for the purpose of making any order authorised thereby, exercise all the powers, vested by this Act in the Commissioners and whereby any other law power is vested in the Commissioners for any purpose, the Chairman may transact any business or make any order authorised by that law in the exercise. of that power, unless it is otherwise expressly provided in that law. Section 20 of the Act provides for sanction of the Local Authority for prosecutions under the Act which includes a Municipality. Reading these two provisions together the Chairman of a Municipality duly authorised by the Municipality can accord sanction for prosecution of offences under the Act.
We accordingly so direct. Subject to this modification, the appeal and the Criminal Miscellaneous Petitions Nos. 450 and 515 of 1970 are dismissed.

edges.explanation: h2 on continuing power for Chairman supports c3 requirement of duly authorised Chairman

anchor.surface_text: In compliance with the aforesaid power under s. 51 of the Bengal Municipal Act, the Municipality by resolution dated July 28, 1960 authorised the Chairman to perform all the functions and exercise the. powers of the Local Authority within the meaning of the Prevention of Food Adulteration Act, 1954.  Exe. 7 . This power, it may be noticed, is not granted to any particular Chairman Eo nomine, but is a general power exercisable by any Chairman for the time being of the Municipality. It is true that a fresh election of the Chairman was held after the resolution of the Municipality but that does not deprive the new Chairman of the power to grant sanction in under that, resolution.
We accordingly so direct. Subject to this modification, the appeal and the Criminal Miscellaneous Petitions Nos. 450 and 515 of 1970 are dismissed.

anchor.surface_text: The High Court has pointed out, and we think rightly, that under s. 15 2  of the Bengal Municipal Act, the Municipality is a body corporate and it has perpetual succession, if so any authorisation granted by it is not limited to the Chairman then in office, but will continue unless otherwise rescinded.
We accordingly so direct. Subject to this modification, the appeal and the Criminal Miscellaneous Petitions Nos. 450 and 515 of 1970 are dismissed.
We accordingly so direct. Subject to this modification, the appeal and the Criminal Miscellaneous Petitions Nos. 450 and 515 of 1970 are dismissed.

edges.explanation: Holding h5 on report effectiveness despite omissions overlaps and supports concept c10 by affirming evidentiary value under PFA s13.
Holding h5 states that omission to report other tests does not make the Public Analyst report ineffective if saponification test fails, directly resolving issue i3.

anchor.surface_text: It is true that the Public Analyst in his report has only indicated the result of the three tests out of which two tests were as indicated in A 17.06 while only one, namely, the saponification test was said to have exceeded the maximum on the strength of which the Public Analyst reported that the sample was adulterated. Omission to report on the other four tests does not, in our view make the reporter ineffective or the report inconclusive. Even assuming that the other four tests are normal, if the saponification test alone did not conform to the standards indicated in A 17.06 of Appendix B to the Rules the sample cannot be said to have come up to the standard and, therefore, it is adulterated.
We accordingly so direct. Subject to this modification, the appeal and the Criminal Miscellaneous Petitions Nos. 450 and 515 of 1970 are dismissed.

edges.explanation: Holding h6 on conclusiveness of Appendix B standards supports holding h5 by establishing that failure of a test like saponification under A.17.06 deems the sample adulterated.

anchor.surface_text: to the standards specified in A 17.06 of Appendix B to the Rules which companytention is also number tenable. Under s. 13  5  of the Act any document

edges.explanation: Holding h6 declares standards in Appendix B to the Rules under s.3 PFA conclusive, directly addressing issue i4 on whether A.17.06 standard in Appendix B is conclusive

anchor.surface_text: We cannot allow any fresh evidence to be used, nor do we think that the decisions referred to, even if they justify that contention, can alter or vary the standard fixed in exercise of the powers conferred by the Act in Appendix B to the Rules. Section 3 of the, Act authorises the Central Government to constitute a Committee called the Central Committee for Food Standards to advise the Central Government and the State Governments on matters arising out of the administration of the Act and to carry out the other functions assigned to it under the Act. Under s. 23 1 b of the Act the Central Government may, after consultation with the Committee and subject to the condition of previous publication, make rules defining the standards of quality for, and fixing the limits of variability permissible in respect of, any article of food. It is in exercise of this power that r. 5 was made authorising standards of quality of the various articles of food specified in Appendix B to the Rules. In view of this provision any article of food which does not conform to the standards specified in Appendix B to the Rules which under s. 2 1 of the Act is said to be adulterated because the quality or purity of the article falls below the prescribed standard or its constituents are present in quantities which are in excess of the prescribed limits of variability.
We accordingly so direct. Subject to this modification, the appeal and the Criminal Miscellaneous Petitions Nos. 450 and 515 of 1970 are dismissed.

edges.explanation: Holding h7 that PA report admissible u/s.13(5) unless CFL directly supports concept c10 on the same PFA Sections 13 admissibility rule.

anchor.surface_text: Under s. 13 5 of the Act any document purporting to be a report signed by a Public Analyst, unless it has been superseded under sub-s. 3 , or any document purporting to be a certificate signed by the Director of the Central Food Laboratory, may be used as evidence of the facts stated therein in any proceeding under the Act or under ss. 272 to 276 of the Indian Penal Code.
We accordingly so direct. Subject to this modification, the appeal and the Criminal Miscellaneous Petitions Nos. 450 and 515 of 1970 are dismissed.
